thread.title: Carnival Spirit victim Kristen Schroder’s fatal decision a ‘dramatic gesture to alarm and test’
thread.title_full: Carnival Spirit victim Kristen Schroder’s fatal decision a ‘dramatic gesture to alarm and test’

author: SARAH CRAWFORD
title: Carnival Spirit victim Kristen Schroder’s fatal decision a ‘dramatic gesture to alarm and test’
text:
IN A “heightened state of emotion”, Ms Schroder made the fateful decision to climb over the railing of a cruise ship in a “dramatic gesture to alarm and test” her boyfriend, leading to both of their deaths.
Deputy State Coroner Hugh Dillon said Ms Schroder, 26, and Paul Rossington, 30, would have experienced “the loneliest of deaths in a dark ocean” when they fell from the Carnival Spirit, 120km of the NSW coast, on May 8, 2013.
On handing down his findings into their deaths, Mr Dillon said Ms Schroder, who had no fear of heights, must have slipped on the narrow, salt-slicked railing and Mr Rossington had shown “conspicuous courage” by jumping after her in a desperate attempt to rescue her. The couple were on a make or break trip. Source: Supplied
Paul Rossington and Kristen Schroder. Source: Supplied
The couple went overboard some time after 8.40pm but their disappearance was not noticed until 10am the next day when they failed to disembark in Sydney.
An air and sea search of 1400sq km by the navy, NSW police and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority failed to find their bodies.
Mr Dillon said Ms Schroder had suffered from anxiety, depression and a sense of insecurity.
The couple of 10 months had a “volatile” relationship and viewed the trip as a “make or break” holiday for their relationship.
Trust was sore spot and there were hangovers from previous relationships. They would oscillate between break-ups and reconciliation. Ms Schroder, family members said, had a “flair for drama”.
Recognising she needed help, she reached out to a psychologist. Paul Rossington’s parents, Christine and Richard outside Glebe Coroner’s court today. Picture: John Grainger Source: News Corp Australia
“My anxiety appears to have spiralled and I’m reacting harshly to Paul,” she wrote months before the cruise.
“I’m really worried I’m losing control and hate that I’m lashing out at the person I care most about in the world and [who] has been the biggest support I could have imagined.
“I don’t like who I am or how I am treating him and I need to figure it out ...”
Mr Rossington, described by the coroner as a “positive, quiet and compassionate man”, found it hard when the pair was forced to live in separate towns.
“At different times, each of them felt that the other was too possessive and demanding,” Mr Dillon said.
There were frequent rows and Mr Rossington told of Ms Schroder once threatening suicide if he left her, though there was no evidence to suggest what happened on the night of May 8, 2013, was anything other than a terrible accident.
Mr Dillon said it was another argument that night which led to Ms Schroder climbing over the railing. CCTV footage of Paul Rossington and Kristen Schroder arguing in the casino shortly before they died. Source: Supplied
Paul Rossington and Kristen Schroder leaves and heads back to his room. Source: Supplied
“Why Kristen stepped over the railing of the cabin is not known. The most likely explanation is that Kristen, being unafraid of heights, was making a dramatic gesture to alarm and test Paul.” Infra-red CCTV footage showed her standing on the outside of the ship for a few seconds before falling.
It then captured Mr Rossington doing a “safety jump” after her.
Mr Dillon said one of the tragic aspects of the case was that what the couple wanted from each other in life they probably achieved by going overboard together.
“What they had struggled to achieve in life, loving unity, they probably managed in their last actions alive.” Kristen Schroder’s mother Roxene Dennis, sister Denise and brother. Picture: John Grainger Source: News Corp Australia
He said he would recommend Mr Rossington for a bravery award as requested by investigating officer Detective Sergeant Michael O’Keefe.
But Mr Dillon said it would be up to the Australian Honours secretariat to recommend him for the Cross of Valour — the highest bravery award.
DESPITE TUMULTUOUS RELATIONSHIP ROSSINGTON TRIED TO SAVE BELOVED
CARNIVAL SPIRIT INQUEST: KRISTEN SCHRODER SLIPPED ON RAIL
CARNIVAL SPIRIT HERO PAUL ROSSINGTON’S FAMILY WILL WAIT FOR AWARD
Det Sgt O’Keefe had told the inquest, held earlier this month, that Mr Rossington deserved the Cross of Valour for his “supreme act of courage”.
Both families attended this morning’s findings. The balcony rail that Kristen Schroder slipped from on the Carnival Spirit. Picture: Adam Taylor Source: News Limited
The Carnival Spirit. Picture: James Morgan Source: Supplied
Mr Rossington’s siblings wore their mother Christeen Rossington’s tartan colours from the Scottish clan of Campbell.
Paul’s brother Trent wore his brother’s kilt for the occasion.
Christeen Rossington said she was “very humbled,” that her son was to be recommended for such a prestigious honour which he would never have sought out.
“Paul was a very humble, quiet man and hated attention being drawn to himself,” she said.
Mr Dillon said man overboard events were “rare” but less so than a sinking ship.
He recommended that passengers receive man overboard instructions as part of the safety briefing when embarking on cruise ships. Paul Rossington’s siblings wore their mother’s family tartan, brother Trent (right) wearing Paul’s kilt. Picture: John Grainger Source: News Corp Australia
Originally published as Pair suffered ‘loneliest of deaths’
